title: 115_hr5603
content: The "Access to Telehealth Services for Substance Use Disorders Act" allows for certain exemptions from Medicare telehealth requirements for the treatment of substance use disorders or co-occurring mental health disorders. The Social Security Act is amended to allow exemptions from Medicare telehealth requirements for treating substance use disorders or co-occurring mental health disorders. The Secretary is authorized to waive certain requirements for telehealth services related to substance use disorder treatment. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for telehealth services for individuals with substance use or mental health disorders. This includes clarifications and limitations on non-application of certain requirements. No facility fee is paid for telehealth services at originating sites. The term 'eligible beneficiary' is defined as an individual entitled to benefits under part A and enrolled for benefits under this part, with a diagnosis for a substance use disorder and meeting other specified criteria. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the impact of not applying certain requirements on health care services and outcomes related to substance use disorder. The Secretary will transfer $3,000,000 from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Program Management Account. This bill aims to amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to grant the Secretary of Health and Human Services authority to waive certain Medicare telehealth requirements in specific cases, while still complying with applicable State laws. Medicare telehealth requirements can be waived in specific cases involving treatment of substance use disorder or co-occurring mental health disorder.
